title: Investigation into the Death of Asos Co-Founder Quentin Griffiths in Thailand
summary: Quentin Griffiths, a British entrepreneur and co-founder of the online fashion giant Asos, died on February 9th after falling from a high-rise apartment block in Pattaya, Thailand. Thai police confirmed the incident, stating he was found deceased outside a luxury hotel where he resided as a long-term tenant in a 17th-floor suite. Initial forensic analysis, including an autopsy, revealed no evidence of foul play, with his room locked from the inside and no signs of forced entry, suggesting the possibility of an accidental fall or suicide. Griffiths co-founded Asos in London in 2000 alongside Nick Robertson, Andrew Regan, and Deborah Thorpe, departing in 2005 but maintaining a significant shareholder position. Asos, originally an acronym for As Seen On Screen, evolved from a niche retailer of celebrity-inspired apparel to a comprehensive online marketplace valued at over £6 billion, with major stakeholders including Anders Holch Povlsen and Mike Ashley. Police indicated Griffiths was embroiled in ongoing court cases, notably a legal dispute with his Thai ex-wife over a joint business venture, which may have contributed to psychological stress. The article synthesizes details from police reports, corporate history, and personal background, offering a nuanced examination of the circumstances surrounding his death within the broader context of his professional legacy and personal challenges.
